- Location: Facade, intercolumnar bandeau
- Date: Unknown, probably Claudius 
- [Hieroglyphic Text](https://www.ifao.egnet.net/uploads/publications/enligne/Temples-Esna002.pdf#page=211){target="_blank"}
- Bibliography: None  
  

<div class="col2">
| *mj m ḥtp*  
| *ẖnm=k pr-wr m pr-m-qd*  
| *ʿq=k ḥw.t-nṯr m nḏm-jb*
|    *wʿb.tw nn ḏw nb ḫr=k*  
|  
| *mḥn=j ḥr tp=k*  
|     *mj nb-ḏr*  
| *mnḥ.n=j tpy.w nw ḫfty.w=k*  
|    *m rn=j pfy n Mnḥy.t*  
|  
| Come in peace![^fn-66_1]  
| Unite with the Per-wer in extasy,  
| enter the temple in joy,  
|    being pure, without evil.  
|  
| I am coiled (*mḥn*) upon your head,  
|     like (I would for) the All Lord,  
| I have cut off (*mnḥ*) the heads of your enemies,
|    in my name of Menhyt (***Mnḥ****y.t*).[^fn-66_2] 
 

</div>

[^fn-66_1]: This text is properly speaking a caption above [Esna 67]. The goddess Menhyt addresses the king while he is being purified by Harsiese and Thoth.

[^fn-66_2]: This entire speech has an exact parallel in *Esna* II, 15, 19.
